dataset.title: MCR LTER: Coral Reef: Diadema predation and recruitment in Moorea, French Polynesia

abstract.para: These are field data from Moorea, French Polynesia regarding the population dynamics of Diadema savignyi. Data were collected during the austral winters in 2009 and 2010. Four datasets are provided: (1) recruitment data of Diadema savignyi over the course of ~9 weeks during the austral winter of 2010, (2) predation data of adult Diadema using a tethering experiment, (3) urchin abundance surveys for 2009 and 2010, and (4) a 9 week weekly survey of newly recruited Diadema (test diameter). These data are part of a PhD dissertation, "Herbivore Community Dynamics and Functional Compositions in Moorea, French Polynesia", 2014, published by ProQuest.

keywordSet.keyword: Richard B. Gump South Pacific Research Station

intellectualRights.para:
Data collected under the auspices of the MCR LTER are available to the public after primary publication, or at most two years after the completion of the study unless proprietary restrictions are warranted. Use of MCR LTER data is subject to acceptance of the following conditions:
1. The user agrees to provide valid name and contact information prior to downloading online data. This information will be used to contact the user in case of changes to the data, and may also be used by data set authors and MCR LTER project administrators to document data usage.
2. The user agrees to cite the data set author and MCR LTER in all publications in which the data are used, as per the instructions in the data documentation. If no specific instructions are provided in the data documentation, the user is requested to include the following statement: "Data sets were provided by the Moorea Coral Reef Ecosystem LTER, funded by the US National Science Foundation (OCE-0417412)."
3. The user agrees to provide one copy of any manuscript based on MCR LTER data to the data set author prior to submitting it for publication.
4. The user agrees to send two hard copies of any published manuscript based on MCR LTER data to the following address: Dr. Andrew J. Brooks Deputy Program Director, MCR LTER Marine Science Institute University of California Santa Barbara, CA 93106-6150 The user also agrees to send one electronic copy (pdf format) to the following e-mail address: brooks@msi.ucsb.edu
5. Users are prohibited from selling or redistributing any data provided by MCR LTER without explicit prior permission.
6. Users are encouraged to contact original investigators responsible for data. Where appropriate, researchers whose projects are integrally dependent on MCR LTER data are encouraged to consider collaboration and/or co-authorship with original investigators.
7. Extensive efforts are made to ensure that online data are accurate and up to date, but the authors and the MCR LTER will not take responsibility for any errors that may exist in data provided online. Furthermore, the user assumes all responsibility for errors in analysis or judgment resulting from use of the data.
8. Any violation of the terms of this agreement will result in immediate forfeiture of the data and loss of access privileges to other MCR LTER data sets.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Island nominal center point: Moorea, French Polynesia

section.title: Diadema predation and recruitment
section.para: Study Site This study was conducted on the island of Moorea, French Polynesia (17 deg, 30 min S, 149 deg, 50 min W). Fieldwork was conducted in a total of 10 study sites, all of which were lagoonal patch-reefs roughly 1-7m in depth. Three of these sites are located along the northern shores of Moorea, between Opunohu Bay and Ava Iti. The remaining seven sites are scattered throughout the eastern shores of the island between Temae and Maatea.

Urchin Abundance Adult Diadema savignyi abundance was estimated annually during the Austral winters of 2009-2010 at each study site using 45 haphazardly placed 1-m2 quadrats. Care was taken to look under coral bommies and crevices for hidden urchins as these surveys were performed during the daytime. Surveys were limited to adult habitat areas only and therefore excluded rubble patches along the reef crest as well as areas consisting only of sand.

Recruitment Surveys were conducted every two weeks in rubble fields from June to August 2010 at each study site to quantify the number of new recruits in an area. Rubble from ten haphazardly placed 1-m2 quadrats were thoroughly searched for D. savignyi individuals at each site. Each rubble piece within the 1-m2 quadrat was manually searched for newly settled urchins until pavement or sand was hit. The test diameter (mm) of each individual was measured by vernier calipers along with the length of rubble (mm) on which an individual was found. Other measurements included the total number of individuals found on a piece of rubble and the depth (mm) of the rubble patch. To determine the amount of growth that occurs in newly settled urchins over the course of two-weeks, 40 individuals with test diameters no larger than 12mm were collected from rubble patches in June 2010 and then transported to the laboratories at the University of California, Berkeley Gump Field Station. Urchins were kept in aquariums with flowing sea-water and given a constant supply of turf algae for a total of 9 weeks. Test diameters (mm) of individuals were measured weekly and the weekly growth rate was calculated using a simple linear regression. The total amount of rubble area for each study site was measured by snorkelers. Transect tapes were used to quantify the width and length (in meters) of each rubble field. The total area of each study site was estimated using the software Google Earth (version 5.2.1) and the amount of total suitable juvenile habitat was calculated by dividing the rubble area by the total amount of reef area. Values were then standardized to amount of rubble per 100m2 of reef.

Mortality Urchins were collected in the field and brought back to the laboratory for tethering. Urchins were tethered using a hypodermic needle and a 14lb test monofilament line (McClanahan and Muthiga 1989). Urchins were tethered in the afternoon and returned to the field the following morning - individuals tethered for longer than 24 hours were not used in these experiments. Ten urchins were tethered along a 20m line at every other meter with each individual urchin having a 1 to 1.5m length of tether. Three 20m lines were strung, for a total of 30 urchins, at each study site with at least 8m between each line. All 30 tethered urchins were strung along the 20m line by 8AM and were observed every hour during daylight hours (typically from 7AM to 5PM) for a total of 48 hours. The first observation for every line occurred 0.5 hours after the urchins were strung and were then observed at every hour afterwards. For each individual urchin, the following measurements were recorded: test diameter (mm), type of shelter, number of hours until the individual was eaten, if the individual was eaten during the experiment, and the type of predator(s) seen eating the individual. Type of shelter was classified as one of four categories: (1) Open - in which an individual had no shelter, (2) Crevice - in which an individual was hidden in some type of shelter, (3) Aggregation - in which an individual was with other D. savignyi urchins, and (4) Aggregation and Crevice - in which an individual was in an aggregation with other urchins but was also underneath some type of shelter. Temporal variation in per capita mortality rate was examined by repeating the tethering experiment three times each at two different study sites. Predator abundance, specifically that of the orange-striped triggerfish, Balistapus undulatus, was recorded over each of the 20m lines. A 5m bandwidth was used such that any B. undulatus that was seen within 2.5m of either side of the 20m line was recorded. Predator abundance was recorded in both the presence and absence of tethered urchins for four successive hours starting at 8AM and ending at 12PM. Habitat complexity was estimated by taking rugosity measurements (straight line distance/bottom contour distance) using the above 20m line (McClanahan and Shafir 1990). Habitat complexity is the highest when rugosity is close to zero and lowest when rugosity equals one.

dataTable.entityDescription: Bi-weekly surveys of recruitment in varying rubble environment

attribute.attributeDefinition: Name of study site. Longitude and latitude coordinates are given for each study site in a separate file.
Date of survey in 2010
10 random 1-meter squared quadrats were surveyed at each study site every two weeks. The replicate number refers to a quadrat number.
Individual ID number: the highest number for a "replicate" corresponds to the total number of Diadema individuals found in that particular quadrat (or replicate)
"Test Diameter" of every individual found within a quadrat (or replicate) in millimeters.

Rubble ID number for a given quadrat (or replicate). The length of the rubble was measured if it had a Diadema individual on it--this provides the number of rubbles associated with having an urchin on it. The highest number for "Rubble" for a given quadrat (or replicate) is the total number of rubble pieces that had a Diadema individual on it.

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: Either did not take rubble information (in the beginning of the survey date) or an individual was not found on a rubble.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Length of the rubble (in centimeters) that an individual urchin was found on.

missingValueCode.codeExplanation: Either did not take rubble information (in the beginning of the survey date) or an individual was not found on a rubble.

dataTable.entityDescription: Survival time tethered on transects and shelter behavior

attribute.attributeDefinition: Location of study site. Names correspond to other data tables with same names.
Trial number: predation experiment was replicated only at 2 sites (LTER1 and Hilton). LTER1 and Hilton have Trial numbers 1 through 3, but all other sites only have trial number 1.
Time (in hours) of death from beginning of experiment (hour 0).
Censorship as used in survival analysis. At the end of the experiment (hour 48), an individual was either dead (censor 0) or still alive (censor 1).

codeDefinition.definition: Individual was dead at the end of the experiment
Individual was still alive at the end of the experiment

attribute.attributeDefinition: Transect ID: three transects, each transect was 20-meters long with an individual tethered at every other meter for a total of 10 individuals per transect.
Test diameter (in millimeters) of the tethered individual.
"Oppenness" is where the individual was the last time I saw the individual in relation to shelters and aggregations.

codeDefinition.definition: An individual was out in the open (i.e. not in a shelter or part of an aggregation)
An individual was in a shelter
An individual was close to an aggregation or a shelter but was not part of an aggregation nor inside the shelter
An individual was part of an aggregation
Did not observe where the individual was before it died
Individual was out in the open but was near an aggregation
Individual was out in the open but was near a shelter

attribute.attributeDefinition: Name of study site: name corresponds to "Location" of other data tables.
Quadrat number: 45 random quadrats were used at each site.
Number of Diadema individuals observed in a particular quadrat.
Number of Echinothrix individuals observed in a quadrat.
Number of Echinometra individuals observed in a quadrat.
Year of survey
Total number of urchins observed in a quadrat

dataTable.entityDescription: Diameter of individual urchins tracked weekly

attribute.attributeDefinition: Date of observation in the austral winter of 2010. Measurements were made weekly in a laboratory setting.

Week number: week 0 corresponds to when the urchins were brought into the laboratory from the field. Individuals were reared in the laboratory for a total of 9 weeks (counting week 0) and test diameters were tracked weekly.

Number of individual. NOTE: individual 1 in week 0 does not correspond to individual 1 in week 1, 2, etc. These are not individual ID's but rather just a count of the number of individuals observed each week. The number of individuals both decreased (some died) and increased (the salt water was not a closed system and individuals may have entered the laboratory set up through the salt water flow system) throughout the experimental time.
Test diameter (in millimeters) of an individual.

ns2:unit.name: dimensionless
ns2:unit.ns2:description: a designation asserting the absence of an associated unit

ns2:unit.name: nominalHour
ns2:unit.ns2:description: one hour excluding leap seconds, 3600 seconds
